author: By Shawn Hubler and Alexander Burns
title: Gavin Newsom has to pick someone to fill Kamala Harris’s Senate seat, and the pressure is mounting.
description: Alex Padilla, California’s secretary of state, has emerged as the front-runner to succeed Vice President-elect Kamala Harris. But Gov. Gavin Newsom appears to be in no rush to make his choice.
content: Alex Padilla, California’s secretary of state, has emerged as the front-runner to succeed Vice President-elect Kamala Harris. But Gov. Gavin Newsom appears to be in no rush to make his choice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: The White House Christmas Decorations Look Strikingly Normal
description: Blood-red trees these are not.
content: The first lady has overseen holiday decorations at the White House since 1961, when Jacqueline Kennedy hung ornaments of toys, birds and angels themed to “The Nutcracker” ballet on a Christmas tree in the Blue Room. This year was no different.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac
title: Facebook to Acquire Start-Up Kustomer as It Faces Antitrust Glare
description: The social network was said to be paying close to $1 billion for the maker of customer relationship management software.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook is facing the glare of regulators for buying up promising start-ups and neutralizing them as a competitive threat. But that hasn’t stopped the social network from shelling out for more companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Agnes Callard
title: I Don’t Want You to ‘Believe’ Me. I Want You to Listen.
description: I fear that the more I tell you, the less you will understand who I am.
content: I am not a private person — quite the opposite — but I do have two secrets. The first concerns some Bad Events that happened to me long ago (yes, it’s the sort of thing you are thinking of), and the second is an unrelated Fact about my neurological makeup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Brady Puts Up a Fight, but It’s Mahomes and the Chiefs’ Day
description: Tyreek Hill had a career day against the Buccaneers with 13 receptions for 269 receiving yards and three touchdowns.
content: Tom Brady floundered for most of Sunday’s game against Kansas City’s incandescent quarterback, Patrick Mahomes. If the game was seen by some as a chance for a passing of the torch from one quarterback to another, from an N.F.L. legend to his heir apparent, that torch — if passed by Brady at least — very likely would have been intercepted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Justice Barrett’s Vote Could Tilt the Supreme Court on Gun Rights
description: For years, conservative justices have said the court disfavors the Second Amendment. Justice Amy Coney Barrett is likely to shift the balance, and a case to help her do so may be knocking.
content: WASHINGTON — Justice Amy Coney Barrett is just starting to make her mark at the Supreme Court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia
title: Living and Performing ‘Femme Queen Joy’
description: Rosa Isabel Rayos, a rapper who goes by Ms. Boogie, wants her work to expand the narrative about Black trans women.
content: Rosa Isabel Rayos, 28, is an Afro-Latina transgender rapper whose goal is to make music that uplifts, supports and encourages Black transgender women — including, at times, herself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Amazon Shopping Needs a Prime Army
description: Why the rush to hire so many people?
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Brazil Amazon Deforestation Hits 12-Year High Under Bolsonaro
description: In 2020, destruction of the world’s largest rainforest rose 9.5 percent from a year earlier to about 4,280 square miles. That’s a little smaller than Connecticut.
content: The scale of deforestation in Brazil’s Amazon rainforest surged to a 12-year high in 2020, official government data showed on Monday, with destruction soaring since President Jair Bolsonaro took office and weakened environmental enforcement.
source.name: The New York Times

title: In Hollywood, Women Are Seen as ‘a Risk’
description: Marielle Heller is an acclaimed director and now, with her role in “The Queen’s Gambit,” a breakout actor. So why is she still offered 30 to 40 percent less pay than a man?
content: Marielle Heller had her big acting break in “The Queens Gambit,” a chess drama that has already been viewed on Netflix by over 60 million households. But prior to her performance as Alma Wheatley, Ms. Heller was already a big name — off the screen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Dorie Greenspan’s Amazing New Cookie
description: A riff on lemon meringue pie, her latest recipe layers a shortbread sablé with lemon curd and shards of meringue.
content: Good morning. Dorie Greenspan introduced me to the mystery novelist Louise Penny this weekend, in a delightful column in The New York Times Magazine that begins in Penny’s fictional Three Pines, a village in Quebec “with a good boulangerie; a bookstore that smells like tea and flowers; a bistro with an excellent chef; and a community of fascinating eccentrics.” Penny’s hero, Chief Inspector Armand Gamache of the Surêté du Québec, appears to be one of those brilliant, gentle investigators in the vein of Martin Walker’s Benoît Courrèges, locally known as Bruno, Chief of Police. And, as with Bruno, food plays a big role in his life. I ordered “Still Life,” the first of the Gamache series as soon as I finished Dorie’s piece.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Donald G. McNeil Jr
title: The Long Darkness Before Dawn
description: With vaccines and a new administration, the pandemic will be tamed. But experts say the coming months “are going to be just horrible.”
content: Each week, good news about vaccines or antibody treatments surfaces, offering hope that an end to the pandemic is at hand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Biden names all-female communications team with Jen Psaki as press secretary.
description: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Sunday announced an all-female White House communications staff, with Jennifer Psaki, a veteran of the Obama administration, in the most visible role as White House press secretary.
content: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Sunday announced an all-female White House communications staff, with Jennifer Psaki, a veteran of the Obama administration, in the most visible role as White House press secretary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley and Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: Cuomo Fears ‘Nightmare of Overwhelmed Hospitals’ as Virus Cases Spike
description: New York will implement an assortment of new emergency measures as the state shifts its focus to a sharp rise in coronavirus-related hospitalizations.
content: Warning that New York had entered a “new phase in the war against Covid,” Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Monday that the state will implement a barrage of new emergency actions, some of which echo the strict measures taken this spring, to stem a rising tide of infections and deaths.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Nov. 30, 2020
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Nov. 30, 2020.
content: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Nov. 30, 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Singer
title: Teaching in the Pandemic: ‘This Is Not Sustainable’
description: Teacher burnout could erode instructional quality, stymie working parents and hinder the reopening of the economy.
content: At Farmington Central Junior High in rural Illinois, classes still start at 8 a.m. But that’s about the only part of the school day that has not changed for Caitlyn Clayton, an eighth-grade English teacher tirelessly toggling between in-person and remote students.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: New York Shifts Its Thinking and Reopens Elementary Schools
description: Middle and high schools will remain closed for now, said Mayor de Blasio, who signaled  changes in managing the system during the pandemic.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: London A.I. Lab Claims Breakthrough That Could Accelerate Drug Discovery
description: Researchers at DeepMind say they have solved “the protein folding problem,” a task that has bedeviled scientists for more than 50 years.
content: Some scientists spend their lives trying to pinpoint the shape of tiny proteins in the human body.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: BTS Debuts at No. 1, and CDs Play a Major Role
description: For a second week in a row, an old-fashioned format has helped push a new release to the top of the Billboard album chart.
content: The music industry has a hot new format, one that can generate huge sales, demonstrate fan loyalty and dominate the weekly charts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Oregon Nurse Is Placed on Leave Over TikTok Video Mocking Masks
description: The nurse’s employer, Salem Health, said the post showed “cavalier disregard for the seriousness of this pandemic.”
content: A nurse in Oregon who mocked the state’s pandemic protocols in a video that circulated on TikTok by saying she does not wear a mask in public has been placed on administrative leave, her employer said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: More Restrictions as the Covid-19 Surge Continues
description: Monday: Any break you might’ve been hoping for over the long weekend was cut short.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Skeptical of Trump’s Plan to Not Count Unauthorized Immigrants in Redistricting
description: The administration’s efforts, which are subject to practical hurdles, would upset a constitutional consensus and could shift political power from Democratic states to Republican ones.
content: WASHINGTON — A skeptical Supreme Court on Monday reacted with frustration and some confusion to President Trump’s plan to exclude unauthorized immigrants from the calculations used to allocate seats in the House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: France to Rewrite Contentious Security Bill on Sharing Images of Police
description: Opposition to a provision that restricts circulating images of on-duty police officers had ballooned over the past week, sending tens of thousands of protesters into streets around France.
content: PARIS — French lawmakers will completely rewrite a legislative provision restricting the sharing of images of police officers that was pushed by the government but has faced fierce opposition over the past week, a top official in President Emmanuel Macron’s party announced on Monday, in an effort to defuse a mounting crisis over the measure.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A global economic recovery cannot be sustained until the virus is thwarted.
description: Nearly a year into a pandemic that has ravaged the global economy, the only clear pathway toward improved fortunes depends on containing the virus.
content: Nearly a year into a pandemic that has ravaged the global economy, the only clear pathway toward improved fortunes depends on containing the virus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Carmel
title: Smithsonian Archives of American Art Gathers an Oral History of 2020
description: The archives took on a new challenge: preserving this moment of pandemic and protest for the future. Those interviewed include Mark Bradford, Ed Bereal and Sheila Hicks.
content: As the pandemic set in this spring, the historians and curators at the Smithsonian Archives of American Art began doing what they do best: looking through relics of history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Simonson
title: What if Cocktail Mixers Were Actually Good?
description: Prefab drink mixes have long had a bad name, but here come several made with natural ingredients and a craft bartender’s sensibility.
content: Adam Kolesar, who makes quality cocktail syrups under the name Orgeat Works in Brooklyn, approached his friend Jeff Berry in 2018 with an offbeat idea: What if they made a Mai Tai mix — like the cocktail mixers you see in the supermarket but, you know, good.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Biden Fractures Foot Playing With His Dog, Putting Him in a Boot
description: The president-elect visited an orthopedic specialist, and while initial X-rays did not show an obvious fracture, a more detailed CT scan showed hairline cracks.
content: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. twisted his ankle playing with  one of his dogs over the holiday weekend, an injury that his doctor said on Sunday resulted in hairline fractures in his foot that would most likely require him to wear a walking boot for several weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: British retailer Arcadia Group, owner of Topshop, files for bankruptcy.
description: Arcadia Group, the British retail company owned by Philip Green that includes the Topshop clothing chain, has gone into administration, a form of bankruptcy, the company said Monday. It is one of the biggest retail collapses in Britain since the start of the pandemic.
content: Arcadia Group, the British retail company owned by Philip Green that includes the Topshop clothing chain, has gone into administration, a form of bankruptcy, the company said Monday. It is one of the biggest retail collapses in Britain since the start of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: No, Georgia’s governor cannot ‘overrule’ its secretary of state on voting.
description: The law prohibits the governor from interfering in elections.
content: President Trump on Monday morning inaccurately described Georgia’s vote counting process and implausibly urged the state’s Republican governor to “overrule” its Republican secretary of state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Denise Grady
title: Moderna Applies for Emergency F.D.A. Approval for Its Coronavirus Vaccine
description: The first shots could be given as early as Dec. 21, if authorization is granted.
content: The drugmaker Moderna announced highly encouraging results on Monday, saying that complete data from a large study show its coronavirus vaccine to be 94.1 percent effective, a finding that confirms earlier estimates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: A Warlord’s Memoir Is Surprisingly Modern and Charming, When It’s Not Gruesome
description: “The Babur Nama” is the autobiography of the polymathic founder of the Mughal dynasty.
content: Zahiru’d-din Muhammad Babur (1483-1530), a descendant of Genghis Khan, was a warlord from Central Asia who invaded India and founded the Mughal dynasty. He kept a record of his life, now known as “The Babur Nama.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Hong Kong’s Courts, Still Independent, Face New Threats From Beijing
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, November 30, 2020.
content: “Beijing may not want to be seen as interfering with judicial independence, but I think it is very clear some Beijing officials are not happy with some decisions made by our judges.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: NATO Needs to Adapt Quickly to Stay Relevant for 2030, Report Urges
description: After France’s president said NATO was suffering “brain death,” the alliance sought advice on how to stay vibrant as it faces new challenges from Russia and China.
content: BRUSSELS — A high-level look at NATO’s next 10 years recommends significant changes to confront the new challenges of an aggressive Russia and a rising China, urging overhauls to fortify the  alliance’s cohesion and to better coordinate with democratic allies around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Shapiro and Kate Taylor
title: Why School Districts Are Bringing Back Younger Children First
description: New York City became the highest-profile example when Mayor de Blasio said elementary schools would reopen starting Dec. 7.
content: After a summer of uncertainty and fear about how schools across the globe would operate in a pandemic, a consensus has emerged in more and more districts: In-person teaching with young children is safer than with older ones and particularly crucial for their development.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Tobias
title: ‘Fargo’ Season 4 Finale Recap: Lessons Learned
description: Ethelrida put the finishing touches on her “history report,” asking questions about who gets to tell histories about Americans whose pasts are segregated.
content: The Coen Brothers film “Fargo” ends, touchingly, with Marge Gunderson, the small-town police chief played by Frances McDormand, talking to a criminal sitting in the back of her squad car (Peter Stormare). She had never witnessed the kind of violence that he and other men have perpetuated, and the events have shaken her, even as her infallible instincts have led her to the right conclusions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hugh Eakin
title: When an Enemy’s Cultural Heritage Becomes One’s Own
description: Could the cease-fire in Nagorno-Karabakh offer new hope for the preservation of threatened monuments everywhere?
content: Since its origins in the ninth century, Dadivank Monastery has withstood Seljuk and Mongol invasions, Persian domination, Soviet rule and, this fall, a second brutal war between Armenia and Azerbaijan. Now the majestic stone complex — which includes two frescoed churches, a bell tower and numerous medieval inscriptions — faces something that could be even worse: a dangerous peace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: A New Outbreak Leaves a Broncos Rookie in an Awkward Position: Quarterback
description: Receiver Kendall Hinton was a last resort fill-in when four Denver Broncos quarterbacks were ruled ineligible to play in Sunday’s game because they’d been exposed to the coronavirus.
content: Before Sunday, Kendall Hinton hadn’t taken a snap for the Denver Broncos at quarterback — not in a game, not in a practice, not in the recesses of his imagination — for a pretty logical reason: He is not a quarterback.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Frishman
title: Hidden in Plain Sight: The Ghosts of Segregation
description: Vestiges of racism and oppression, from bricked-over segregated entrances to the forgotten sites of racial violence, still permeate much of America’s built environment.
content: The six faded letters are all that remain, and few people notice them. I would never have seen them if a friend hadn’t pointed them out to me while we walked through New Orleans’s French Quarter. I certainly wouldn’t have realized their significance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Finn Cohen
title: Noah Hawley Isn’t Done with ‘Fargo’
description: “The show has always been about the American experience, and there’s still a lot to say about it,” said the creator of the FX crime drama, which wrapped up its fourth season on Sunday night.
content: When the third season of “Fargo” ended in 2017, the concept of “alternative facts” and “fake news” were clearing the way for what became the Trump presidency’s challenge to reality. The themes the creator Noah Hawley explored in that season seemed oddly prescient, all the way down to Russians and disinformation, but he shrugged it off: “You can never predict the zeitgeist,” he said at the time. “I just managed to land in it.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: Accepting the Danger of Human Rights Work in Egypt, With Food and Humor
description: Before his recent arrest, Gasser Abdel-Razek had no illusions about the risks in being a leading rights advocate under the increasingly repressive el-Sisi regime.
content: CAIRO — On bad days — and, in recent years, there seemed to be more bad days than ever — Gasser Abdel-Razek, captain, counselor and friend to nearly everyone in Egypt’s shrinking human rights community, tended to counter the tension and stress with food.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Companies Bet Big on Working From Home
description: Salesforce’s approach for Slack is a sign of things to come.
content: Salesforce has approached Slack about a deal, DealBook hears, confirming a report in The Wall Street Journal. A takeover could be announced as soon as this week. The potential deal is a bet on remote working, an area that bankers tell us will be a hot spot for consolidation in the months ahead, as highly valued software companies look to roll up the fragmented market for collaboration tools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: J.D. Heyman, Entertainment Weekly’s top editor, is out.
description: Meredith Corporation has parted ways with J.D. Heyman, the editor in chief of Entertainment Weekly magazine, the company confirmed on Monday.
content: Meredith Corporation has parted ways with J.D. Heyman, the editor in chief of Entertainment Weekly magazine, the company confirmed on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: G.M. Scales Back Alliance With Electric Truck Start-Up Nikola
description: A new agreement, supplying hydrogen fuel cell technology from General Motors, is narrower than the partnership outlined in September.
content: Nikola, a start-up electric truck company that had made a big splash on Wall Street, announced a broad alliance with General Motors in September that promised to give the company critical technology, financial support and credibility with investors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith
title: Group Seeking Equality for Women in Tech Raises $11 Million
description: The nonprofit organization, All Raise, is working on an expansion, as diversity in the tech industry remains elusive.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Two years ago, fed up with stories of harassment and discrimination in Silicon Valley, a group of female venture capitalists formed a nonprofit called All Raise to focus on women’s equality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scaachi Koul
title: A Peek at the Variety, Wonder and Trauma of Black Life, Then and Now
description: In “Black Futures,” Kimberly Drew and Jenna Wortham compile a nonlinear, multimedia compendium to inspire readers of all races to fight for racial justice.
content: BLACK FUTURES By Kimberly Drew and Jenna Wortham
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: There’s Another Runoff in Georgia, and the Winner Gets a Month in Congress
description: The winner of Tuesday’s runoff will have the distinction of succeeding John Lewis, a giant of the civil rights era, and serving what would have been the final days of his 17th term in Congress.
content: ATLANTA — Kwanza Hall and Robert M. Franklin Jr. have been campaigning for months, planting signs in grassy medians along busy Atlanta roadways and onto windows of popular brunch spots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi and Constant Méheut
title: France’s Major Literary Juries Award Prizes in a Year of Scandal
description: Seven years ago, the judges behind France’s second-biggest literary prize honored a pedophile writer, Gabriel Matzneff. Now, they have turned to a little-known female writer from a small publisher.
content: PARIS — In its first award since a pedophilia scandal revealed deep-rooted collusion within its ranks, one of France’s top literary juries avoided the appearance of any potential conflicts of interest on Monday by crowning the novel of a little-known female author from a small publishing house.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Path of Virus Deaths
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: The number of Covid-19 deaths in the U.S. has dropped in the last few days, but there is reason to think the decline is a statistical mirage — and that deaths are on the verge of surging again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura
title: Food Delivery Apps Are Booming. Their Workers Are Often Struggling.
description: Delivery drivers have been essential to feeding New York, while boosting sales for companies like DoorDash and Uber. But they say work conditions have gotten worse.
content: When the pandemic lockdown led the Manhattan restaurant where Natanael Evangelista was an employee to close for good, he quickly shifted to working for food delivery apps. He had few options. He was undocumented, did not speak much English and needed money badly. He owed months’ worth of rent, and his family in Mexico needed help.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Coronavirus, Tigray, France: Your Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: Despite Pandemic Shutdowns, Cancer Doesn’t Take a Break
description: The danger of delayed screenings is greatest for people with known risk factors for cancer.
content: While a raging pandemic continues to force shutdowns and slowdowns throughout the country, another major risk to human health is not taking a sabbatical: cancer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: France Thought It Could Reverse Globalization, but It’s Still Bleeding Jobs
description: The government is encouraging more factories, but C.E.O.s say labor costs in the country remain high.
content: PARIS — In recent months, Fabrice Chabance has had plenty to keep him awake at night. Two foreign-owned factories in Saint-Florent-sur-Cher, a region of 11,000 people where he is a political leader, have announced plans to move parts of their production lines to countries with lower labor costs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Embracing My Inner Bob Ross
description: While covering an exhibit of the famous PBS artist, I replaced my notebook with an easel and experienced even more of the joy of reporting.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nathaniel Popper
title: Bitcoin Hits New Record, This Time With Less Talk of a Bubble
description: The crazy cousin of traditional currencies, which fell below $4,000 in March, passed $19,783. More investors now are buying it for the long term.
content: Bitcoin is back. Again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley, Jeanna Smialek and Alan Rappeport
title: Biden’s Economic Team Suggests Focus on Workers and Income Equality
description: In the White House and elsewhere, the president-elect’s selections are heavy on labor economists and champions of organized labor.
content: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. formally announced his top economic advisers on Monday, choosing a team that is stocked with champions of organized labor and marginalized workers, signaling an early focus on efforts to speed and spread the gains of the recovery from the pandemic recession.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James B. Stewart, Collier Schorr and Mel Ottenberg
title: Barbra Streisand Is, as Ever, Firmly in Control
description: Since her breakout in the 1960s, she’s been able to convince the world around her to listen — not by chasing trends but by remaining always and fully herself.
content: THE DAY I arrive at Barbra Streisand’s property, she is on the phone with the Christie’s auction house in London. Outside, it’s a brilliantly sunny California afternoon in October, the skies clear of the ash cloud that recently blanketed Los Angeles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hanya Yanagihara
title: Celebrating Three of America’s Most Beloved Divas
description: Patti LaBelle, Dolly Parton and Barbra Streisand may each be synonymous with a different musical style, but they are alike in their ability to bring joy.
content: I had just begun writing this letter when my downtown Manhattan neighborhood erupted in sound: people yelling, cars honking, noisemakers blowing. It was Nov. 7, 2020, and the presidential election had finally been called for Joe Biden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Brandy Houser, Hospice Care Consultant Who Loved Disney, Dies at 41
description: Ms. Houser was a karaoke enthusiast and “pop culture ninja,” her husband said. She died of the coronavirus.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

title: When and How You’ll Get a Vaccine
description: Multiple inoculations for the coronavirus are making their way through the approval process. Here’s what we know about the plan for their distribution.
content: For Americans, months of collective isolation and fear could soon be winding down. A viable coronavirus vaccine may be just weeks away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: Biden begins receiving intelligence briefings as president-elect.
description: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Vice President-elect Kamala Harris received on Monday their first full intelligence briefings since the election, transition officials announced.
content: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Vice President-elect Kamala Harris received on Monday their first full intelligence briefings since the election, transition officials announced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: California Governor Blocks Release of Manson Follower Leslie Van Houten
description: Gov. Gavin Newsom reversed a decision by the state parole board granting her release after about 50 years in prison.
content: A Charles Manson follower who is serving a life sentence for her role in the grisly double murder of a Los Angeles couple more than 50 years ago has lost her latest bid at freedom after California’s governor overrode a parole board’s decision granting her release.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: A Census Case That Goes to the Heart of American Democracy
description: For two centuries, census totals used to apportion Congress have included all residents. The Supreme Court on Monday heard the Trump administration’s argument for only counting citizens.
content: On Monday, the Supreme Court heard arguments on a question that goes to the heart of American democracy: Must the government count everyone living in the country, citizens or not, in the census totals that the House of Representatives uses to reallocate its 435 seats among the states?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari and Michael Corkery
title: ‘Bleak Friday’ for Stores as Pandemic Pushes Holiday Shopping Online
description: Foot traffic was down considerably and internet sales surged during a holiday weekend altered by the coronavirus.
content: The 2020 edition of Black Friday did not offer the usual scenes of bustling stores and shoppers lined up outside discount chains and electronics retailers. Instead, most people bought online, if they bought at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush and Michael D. Shear
title: Georgia’s Republican governor and secretary of state rebuff Trump’s efforts to subvert the election.
description: Two top Georgia Republicans who President Trump has attacked in his postelection campaign to subvert President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory in the state forcefully pushed back against the White House on Monday.
content: Two top Georgia Republicans who President Trump has attacked in his postelection campaign to subvert President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory in the state forcefully pushed back against the White House on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yewande Komolafe
title: Let This Festive Brandied Fruit Lift Your Holidays
description: A family tradition inspired Yewande Komolafe’s spiced and steeped fruit mix, which you could add to cocktails and scones, or serve alongside braised lamb.
content: This year, I have made a conscious effort to revisit the memories of holidays past, and those memories have been kind to me. They have allowed me to recall my family’s traditions, and to feel connected to loved ones in a challenging time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Lower case numbers around Thanksgiving may be misleading.
content: Welcome back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosa Brooks
title: It’s Time for a Woman to Run the Defense Department
description: If Joe Biden chooses a woman as his secretary of defense, he would send an important and long overdue message.
content: President-elect Joe Biden has begun to announce his intended cabinet nominees, and it’s an impressive and diverse group: his picks include an experienced African-American diplomat for ambassador to the United Nations; the first Latino nominated as homeland security secretary; and the first woman tapped to serve as director of national intelligence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eilene Zimmerman
title: Can a Start-Up Mentality Save Small Businesses?
description: Small-business owners are having to learn approaches like “fail fast,” course-correcting and going virtual — and some are succeeding.
content: In early February, things were looking good for Practice San Francisco, a center offering individual psychotherapy and classes for children and adults that promote physical and mental well-being. Business was so good that owner Nina Kaiser, a psychologist, had just renovated and moved into a bigger space with the goal of doubling revenue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow
title: What the Heck Is That?
description: A look at one of the entries that stumped solvers in last week’s puzzles.
content: UNIX was the first operating system designed to work on multiple platforms. It has appeared in the New York Times Crossword 31 times, most recently in the Nov. 26 puzzle by Neville Fogarty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon and Judith Levitt
title: Online Shopping, Virus in Winter, Stock Market: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced
title: S&P Global agrees to buy IHS Markit, a financial data powerhouse, for $44 billion.
description: IHS Markit itself was the product of a 2016 merger between IHS, which was founded in 1959 as a repository for aerospace data, and Markit, which was created in 2003 as a
content: S&P Global, the owner of stock indexes like the Dow and the S&P 500, said on Monday that it plans to acquire IHS Markit for $44 billion, including debt. The transaction would create a financial information powerhouse at a time when data increasingly fuels automated trading.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Anthony Neal, Hank Willis Thomas, Deb Willis and Alex Harrington
title: Patti LaBelle, the Doyenne of Philadelphia Soul
description: At 76, she is the embodiment of success, the personification of warmth and an artist who changed the landscape of American music.
content: PATTI LABELLE’S superpower is a spellbinding scream — a refined shriek, really — that makes hairs stand at attention, bones shiver and spines twist. It was 1975 when I first heard it. I was 10, in my parents’ South Bronx tenement, where the radio station WBLS — offering “the total Black experience in sound,” as the promos said — was always on during our morning rush to school. That’s when it hit me — “Creole Lady Marmalaaaaade,” the last word of those titular lyrics, which debuted the year before, filling the air. My first Patti LaBelle moment. There have been many such moments since — like hearing “Love, Need and Want You” (1983), which I put on the very first slow-jam tape I made as a teen — and with each one, the only logical reaction is to throw up your hands, kick off your shoes and, on occasion, break out in a praise dance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman and Gillian R. Brassil
title: New York Road Runners Parts Ways With C.E.O. Amid Workplace Complaints
description: Michael Capiraso led the organization that puts on the New York City Marathon to record revenues but will leave after employees and others raised concerns about his leadership.
content: The New York Road Runners, the club that puts on the New York City Marathon, announced Monday that its chief executive would depart at the end of the year, amid complaints from current and former employees who questioned the organization’s commitment to diversity, social justice and gender equality as well as its financial management.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Badger
title: Most Republicans Say They Doubt the Election. How Many Really Mean It?
description: Survey research tries to sort out the typical partisan reactions to a loss from an erosion of trust that may be more lasting.
content: Since the election, surveys have consistently found that about 70 percent to 80 percent of Republicans don’t buy the results. They don’t agree that Joe Biden won fair and square. They say the election was rigged. And they say enough fraud occurred to tip the outcome.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: ‘We’ve Harmed the Senate Enough’: Why Joe Manchin Won’t Budge on the Filibuster
description: The moderate senator from West Virginia has a message for his fellow Democrats on muscling through sweeping change.
content: WASHINGTON — Senator Joe Manchin III of West Virginia, the most conservative member of his party in the Senate, has a message for fellow Democrats hoping to capture the majority and quickly begin muscling through legislation to bring about sweeping, liberal change: not on his watch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe
title: Ajit Pai, the Republican F.C.C. chair, will leave on Inauguration Day.
description: Ajit V. Pai, the Republican chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, said Monday that he would leave his post the day that President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. is sworn in, capping a tenure of sweeping deregulation across the telecommunications industry.
content: Ajit V. Pai, the Republican chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, said Monday that he would leave his post the day that President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. is sworn in, capping a tenure of sweeping deregulation across the telecommunications industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: Michel Robin, Longtime French Character Actor, Dies at 90
description: Best known in the United States for his role in the 2001 film “Amélie,” he was a staple of the Comédie-Française theater company, and a familiar supporting actor in dozens of movies.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport, Jim Tankersley, Michael D. Shear and Jeanna Smialek
title: Biden’s picks for his economic team signal a focus on workers.
description: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. officially named top members of his economic team on Monday,  showcasing his commitment to diversity and placing several women in top economic roles.
content: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. officially named top members of his economic team on Monday,  showcasing his commitment to diversity and placing several women in top economic roles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $3 Million Homes in California
description: A Tudor Revival with seven bedrooms in Berkeley, a Craftsman bungalow with five bedrooms in San Diego and an Italianate house with four bedrooms in Napa.
content: This house, in the Claremont neighborhood, was built by Walter H. Ratcliff, a London-born architect who designed a number of Bay Area buildings in the English Tudor style. The home has undergone several transformations: A second gable was added in the 1920s, and in the mid-20th century, interior walls and bathrooms were added so it could be used as a boardinghouse. The current owners turned it back into a single-family residence and updated the plumbing, electrical and HVAC systems. The house is about two blocks from the Clark Kerr Campus of the University of California, Berkeley; the school’s main campus is 10 minutes away. Monkey Island, a small park, is across the street.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: What We Learned From Week 12 of the N.F.L. Season
description: The Titans demolished the Colts, the Chiefs won again and the Broncos, with no quarterback, were crushed in a week defined as much by the coronavirus as the action on the field.
content: With the coronavirus sweeping through the N.F.L. at a greater extent than it had all season, Week 12 had an uneasy edge to it, and several teams had to cobble together solutions to problems brought by player absences resulting from positive tests and close contacts. The league soldiered on, however, getting all 12 of Sunday’s games in regardless of the issues. But a Tuesday game in which as many as 20 Ravens players could be out because of a coronavirus outbreak still looms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jochen Bittner
title: 1918 Germany Has a Warning for America
description: Donald Trump’s “Stop the Steal” campaign recalls one of the most disastrous political lies of the 20th century.
content: HAMBURG, Germany — It may well be that Germans have a special inclination to panic at specters from the past, and I admit that this alarmism annoys me at times. Yet watching President Trump’s “Stop the Steal” campaign since Election Day, I can’t help but see a parallel to one of the most dreadful episodes from Germany’s history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Shopping for Benches
description: Because you need a place to sit near the front door — unless you want to kneel while you’re putting on and taking off your winter boots.
content: If you’re tired of kneeling to lace up your shoes or forcing guests to squat while they’re removing their footwear, it might be time for an entryway bench.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ethan Hauser, James Gorman, Melina Delkic and Michael Gold
title: ‘Assume that you were exposed’: Officials warn of the fallout from Thanksgiving travel.
description: While many in the United States celebrated a muted Thanksgiving over Zoom, millions of people traveled instead, rejecting the advice of public officials.
content: While many in the United States celebrated a muted Thanksgiving over Zoom, millions of people traveled instead, rejecting the advice of public officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Your Honor’ and ‘The Disney Holiday Singalong’
description: Bryan Cranston stars in a new mini-series on Showtime. And singers including Leslie Odom Jr. and Katy Perry appear in a Disney special.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Nov. 30 — Dec. 6. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: For Manchin, a Divided Senate Is a ‘Golden Opportunity’ for Action
description: Frustrated by the dysfunction on Capitol Hill, Senator Joe Manchin III is eager to cut bipartisan deals and check what he views as progressive overreach in the Biden administration.
content: WASHINGTON — A year ago, Joe Manchin III was ready to quit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Schulten
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘The Exquisite Angst of Applying to College in a Deeply Anxious Year’
description: In this lesson, students will consider their own college-admissions journeys by understanding the traditional steps in the process and how this year has disrupted them.
content: Featured Article: “The Exquisite Angst of Applying to College in a Deeply Anxious Year,” by Anemona Hartocollis
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy
title: Hong Kong’s Courts Are Still Independent. Some Want to Rein Them In.
description: The judiciary is crucial to the city’s status as a global hub for trade and finance. But the Chinese Communist Party has been gaining more authority over it.
content: HONG KONG — They were arrested on one of the most violent days in Hong Kong last year, when protesters threw firebombs at the main government offices and set a barrier aflame outside Police Headquarters. But last month, a judge quickly dismantled the prosecutors’ case against them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: A Ham’s ‘Christmas Carol,’ Without the Honey Glaze
description: The astonishing Jefferson Mays stars as everyone (and a potato) in a dark and pointed adaptation of the Dickens holiday classic.
content: Charles Dickens knew how to sell “A Christmas Carol.” For years, he even took it on tour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: On TikTok, Fans Are Making Their Own ‘Ratatouille’ Musical
description: Thousands of TikTok users, including musical theater professionals, are creating a Broadway-style adaptation of the animated Disney film about a rat with culinary aspirations.
content: With Broadway and theaters across the country idle because of the coronavirus, some actors, producers and prop designers have found an unlikely outlet for their talents: a musical version of the animated film “Ratatouille” that is playing out in exuberant 60-second increments on TikTok.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic and Dani Blum
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Tens of thousands of farmers blocked New Delhi roads.
content: Tens of thousands of farmers have blocked roads into New Delhi in recent days to protest new pro-market agricultural policies. A standoff is taking hold in the capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: How Will Biden Deal With Republican Sabotage?
description: He needs to make the G.O.P. pay a price for obstruction.
content: When Joe Biden is inaugurated, he will immediately be confronted with an unprecedented challenge — and I don’t mean the pandemic, although Covid-19 will almost surely be killing thousands of Americans every day. I mean, instead, that he’ll be the first modern U.S. president trying to govern in the face of an opposition that refuses to accept his legitimacy. And no, Democrats never said Donald Trump was illegitimate, just that he was incompetent and dangerous.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Schaverien
title: The lockdown is exposing the gender gap in British sports.
description: When Lisa Bloor heard that her daughter Abby’s elite-level soccer club was being shut down in England’s latest coronavirus lockdown, she faced a tough problem: how to explain that boys at the same level were allowed to keep playing.
content: When Lisa Bloor heard that her daughter Abby’s elite-level soccer club was being shut down in England’s latest coronavirus lockdown, she faced a tough problem: how to explain that boys at the same level were allowed to keep playing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Donald G. McNeil Jr
title: Berry-Flavored H.I.V. Medication Is Ready for Babies
description: For the 80,000 children who die of H.I.V. each year, drugs are often bitter or hard to swallow. Dolutegravir will soon come in a tasty dissolving tablet.
content: The first infant formulation of dolutegravir, an important first-line H.I.V. medication, will be available soon under an agreement between several pharmaceutical companies and global health initiatives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise
title: It may be weeks before we know if Thanksgiving travel fed a virus surge.
description: Four experts agreed that there will be an upward bump in cases linked to the holiday, but they had different estimates for when it would emerge.
content: Did Thanksgiving gatherings and travel accelerate the spread of the coronavirus in the United States, as many experts had feared? When will we be able to tell?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Major Winter Storm Brings Snow, Heavy Rain and Wind to East Coast
description: Forecasters are watching “a strong storm system” that will cover a long swath of the East Coast, from Georgia to New England.
content: The first major winter storm of the season is expected to bring heavy snow, widespread rain and “strong-to-severe” thunderstorms to the East Coast through Wednesday, National Weather Service forecasters said. Some areas were already seeing scattered power failures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: The King of Trump TV Thinks You’re Dumb Enough to Buy It
description: Chris Ruddy, the C.E.O. of Newsmax, has found a business opportunity in feeding Trump supporters the fantasy that the president could still win the election.
content: In 2004, Hillary Clinton was in the Senate and Christopher Ruddy had some making up to do. He was, back then, best known as “the Inspector Clouseau” of the Vince Foster case — a New York Post reporter who had popularized the baseless theory that Mrs. Clinton’s friend, who committed suicide in 1993, had been murdered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Concepción de León
title: Florida Man Rescued After Hours Clinging to Capsized Boat
description: After two unexpected nights at sea and a Coast Guard search, Stuart Bee was rescued from the water by a passing freight ship.
content: A Florida man who had been reported missing at sea was found clinging to his capsized boat on Sunday morning about 86 miles off the coast of Port Canaveral, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Corkery and Sapna Maheshwari
title: Online shopping set a Black Friday record as consumers stayed home.
description: This year’s Black Friday looked nothing like a usual one. Crowds at suburban malls and city shopping districts were comparatively sparse. With the coronavirus touching virtually every corner of the United States, social distancing, restrictions on business activity and health concerns kept many people home.
content: This year’s Black Friday looked nothing like a usual one. Crowds at suburban malls and city shopping districts were comparatively sparse. With the coronavirus touching virtually every corner of the United States, social distancing, restrictions on business activity and health concerns kept many people home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman, Karan Deep Singh and Hari Kumar
title: Angry Farmers Choke India’s Capital in Giant Demonstrations
description: Tens of thousands have arrived in tractors and trailers, many traveling hundreds of miles, to block roads into New Delhi and protest recently passed pro-market agricultural policies.
content: NEW DELHI — Mewa Singh said he wasn’t going anywhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: Median Home Price Sets New Record in California
description: The pandemic paused the housing market for a few months, but it has been on a rebound that has pushed the median price over $700,000.
content: Fueled by low interest rates and a historic housing shortage, California’s median home price in September reached $712,430, closing out four straight months of record highs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Arizona and Wisconsin Certify Biden’s Wins: ‘The System Is Strong’
description: President Trump’s push to reverse the election results in key swing states fell short again as two states carried narrowly by Joe Biden formally signed off on their results.
content: Arizona and Wisconsin on Monday certified President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. as the winner in their presidential elections, formalizing his victory in two additional battleground states as President Trump’s effort to overturn the results of the election continued to fall short.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura
title: Food delivery apps are booming, while their workers often struggle.
description: With New York City’s unemployment rate at 13.2 percent, many people have turned to working for food delivery apps like DoorDash, Uber Eats and Grubhub, which have seen huge demand from customers.
content: With New York City’s unemployment rate at 13.2 percent, many people have turned to working for food delivery apps like DoorDash, Uber Eats and Grubhub, which have seen huge demand from customers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: For Trump, Past Is Prologue
description: He has always tried to weave a reality different from what is actually true.
content: If you are having a hard time fathoming how Donald Trump could deny reality, attempt to force-feed America his fictions, fight truth with conspiracy and concoction, and try to spin a loss into a victory, you shouldn’t. You need only be open to a fair analysis of Trump’s life. There is nothing new about this man’s behavior. This is what he has always been: a liar, a con man and a grifter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Perri Klass, M.D
title: New Guidelines Cover Opioid Use After Children’s Surgery
description: Parents should not be afraid of managing the child’s pain with opioids when they are needed, but should make sure a child does not have access to leftover doses.
content: Opioids are very effective drugs for managing pain, but they can also be scary drugs, with their potential for misuse and abuse. Given the current opioid epidemic in the United States, some parents worry about whether they are safe for children, while many pain experts worry that fear of opioids among parents and among physicians may contribute to the undertreatment of pediatric pain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: As Iran Mourns Nuclear Scientist, Officials Vow to Find His Killers
description: “We chase the criminals to the end,” the Iranian defense minister said at the funeral of Mohsen Fakhrizadeh.
content: The Iranian defense minister vowed on Monday to find and punish those responsible for the assassination of Iran’s top nuclear scientist, while another senior official offered an account of the attack radically different from initial reports in the Iranian state news media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maeve Higgins
title: 128 Tricky Questions That Could Stand Between You and U.S. Citizenship
description: ‘‘Name one example of an American innovation.” Umm … “Real Housewives”? Skyscrapers? This test?
content: Take it from me, a noncitizen, there is much to learn from the naturalization test, one of the final hurdles an immigrant must clear to become a citizen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur
title: A Gymnastics Coach Accused of Emotional Abuse Speaks Out
description: In her first public remarks since being suspended from the sport for eight years, Maggie Haney disputed accusations that led to her punishment but said she could now see flaws in the way she treated some young athletes.
content: If she could travel back in time, before she was suspended from gymnastics after being accused of berating and mistreating her athletes, including an Olympic champion, Maggie Haney says she would change the way she coached.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech
title: ‘Trump Is Better’: In Asia, Pro-Democracy Forces Worry About Biden
description: The president-elect’s aim of returning normalcy to foreign policy has spooked human rights defenders in Asia, who see President Trump as someone who confronted dictators.
content: BANGKOK — A dissident once branded Enemy No. 1 by the Chinese Communist Party is spreading conspiracy theories about the American presidential election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Ransomware Attack Closes Baltimore County Public Schools
description: The attack, first discovered late Tuesday, disrupted the district’s websites and remote learning programs, as well as its grading and email systems, officials said.
content: The public schools in Baltimore County, Md., will remain closed Monday and Tuesday as officials respond to a cyberattack that forced the district to cancel remote classes for its 115,000 students just before the Thanksgiving holiday, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Lordi and Craig McDean
title: The Grit and Glory of Dolly Parton
description: More than 50 years into her legendary career, she’s still capturing America’s particular mythology — its dreams and its disappointments — like no other.
content: IN JUNE OF 1967, Dolly Parton sat down for an interview with a Nashville writer named Everett Corbin. Parton was 21, and had yet to release her first solo album, but the surviving audio recording reveals that she was already shaping her account of herself with the editorial finesse of a one-woman P.R. firm: “I was born — we’ll start with when I was born, OK? — I was born on January the 19th, in 1946, in Sevier County, in Sevierville, Tenn. It’s a little town between Knoxville, Tenn., and Gatlinburg, Tenn. And you might shorten it by saying, ‘the foothills of the Great Smoky Mountains.’” Parton dutifully answers Corbin’s questions (telling him she most enjoys writing and singing “real strong, pitiful, sad, crying ballads”), before steering the conversation toward a topic he hasn’t asked about, but should have: “Well, I have a new album out, I didn’t mention — or it’s not out, but … it should be out by the end of this month. But it’s called ‘Hello, I’m Dolly.’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Biden Moves on to Economic Hires
description: Some of his foreign policy choices present an ethics test: This is your morning tip sheet.
content: Fauci warns of a surge “superimposed” on the one we’re already in, while Biden’s foreign policy team faces a test on ethics. It’s Monday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Black Teenager Is Fatally Shot in Argument Over Music, Police Say
description: The authorities in Ashland, Ore., said they were investigating whether the killing of Aiden Ellison after a confrontation in a hotel parking lot had been “driven by race.”
content: A Black teenager was shot and killed last week in Oregon by an older man who had confronted him in a hotel parking lot for playing loud music, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Vineyard
title: Hugh Grant and David E. Kelley Discuss the ‘Undoing’ Finale
description: Kelley, who created the murder mystery, and the star Grant also tie up some loose ends.
content: This interview includes spoilers for Sunday’s finale of “The Undoing.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Singer
title: Teachers face a steepening toll during the pandemic.
description: All through the fall, teachers have been at the center of vehement debates over whether to reopen schools for in-person instruction — often vilified for challenging it, sometimes praised for trying to make it work.
content: All through the fall, teachers have been at the center of vehement debates over whether to reopen schools for in-person instruction — often vilified for challenging it, sometimes praised for trying to make it work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: New Zealand Announces Charges in Deadly White Island Volcano Eruption
description: Government agencies and individuals were among those charged over the roles in the 2019 disaster, which killed 22 people.
content: WELLINGTON, New Zealand — Almost one year to the day after a deadly volcanic eruption killed 22 people on New Zealand’s White Island, the country’s workplace safety regulator has charged a number of organizations and individuals for their roles in the disaster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and Adam Pasick
title: Reopening Whiplash in New York City
description: Schools will reopen as abruptly as they closed — but only for some.
content: Parents, teachers and children had only a few days to get used to the nation’s biggest school district shutting classrooms before Mayor Bill de Blasio announced another plot twist on Sunday: Students in pre-K and elementary school would return to school after all, starting on Dec. 7.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Prisons Are Covid-19 Hotbeds. When Should Inmates Get the Vaccine?
description: Federal officials have suggested that corrections staff receive high priority for a coronavirus vaccine, but not the millions of vulnerable inmates held in U.S. facilities.
content: They live in crowded conditions, sharing bathrooms and eating facilities where social distancing is impossible. They have high rates of asthma, diabetes and heart disease.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley
title: The head of the Tokyo Stock Exchange resigns over its trading shutdown
description: The company that runs the world’s third largest equities platform announced the executive would step down to take responsibility for a disruption that shook investor confidence.
content: The head of the Tokyo Stock Exchange resigned on Monday, nearly two months after a technical glitch at the exchange shut down equities trading across Japan in a major if temporary disruption to the financial markets in the world’s third largest economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall
title: Police Body Cameras Cited as ‘Powerful Tool’ Against Stop-and-Frisk Abuses
description: City police officers who were assigned body cameras documented more stops than officers who did not wear the devices during a yearlong pilot program.
content: Police body cameras can help reduce the kind of bogus stops that have fueled accusations of racial bias and harassment against police officers in New York City, according to a long-awaited report released Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Barbra Streisand, Patti LaBelle and Dolly Parton on Their Most Memorable Performances
description: The legendary singers share their favorite moments captured onscreen over the years.
content: T’s Dec. 6 Holiday issue honors three American divas — Barbra Streisand, Patti LaBelle and Dolly Parton. Since the ’60s, when their careers began, each has, as Hanya Yanagihara writes in her Editor’s Letter, become “synonymous with an iconic American musical style: the Broadway show tune (Streisand), country (Parton) and soul (LaBelle),” bringing us infinite delight through their “music, acting and sheer force of personality.” Below, we’ve rounded up clips of each artist’s most treasured performances — or most memorable moments — that, when presented altogether, showcase their range, their brilliance and the indelible mark they’ve made on the culture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi, Constant Méheut and Antonella Francini
title: Positive Test Rate of 11 Percent? France’s Schools Remain Open.
description: Many European nations have managed to flatten the coronavirus surge while keeping schools open, reducing academic and economic disruption.
content: PARIS — As a second lockdown appeared inevitable amid skyrocketing coronavirus infections, the scientists advising the French government in October warned that keeping students in their classrooms meant it would take longer to tame the surge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka and Austin Ramzy
title: Australia Condemns Lurid Tweet by Chinese Official as ‘Disgusting Slur’
description: The post, with a doctored photograph showing an Australian soldier with a knife to the throat of an Afghan child, sent relations between the two countries to a new low.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — Labeling it a “disgusting slur,” Prime Minister Scott Morrison of Australia denounced on Monday what he called a fabricated image posted to Twitter by a Chinese official that showed an Australian soldier with a knife to the throat of an Afghan child.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: Do Marriage Proposals Still Have a Place in Today’s Society?
description: When you hear stories about marriage proposals or see them on TV, is your reaction ‘How romantic!’ or do you think the tradition is outdated?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley
title: For Japanese Princess, Fairy-Tale Wedding May Be Distant Prospect
description: Crown Prince Akishino said he approved of his daughter’s marriage to a commoner but noted that the public may be opposed, dimming prospects for an official ceremony.
content: When Princess Mako of Japan became engaged to her college boyfriend in 2017, many Japanese hoped for a fairy-tale wedding for the couple.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: When Can We Stop Thinking About Trump Every Minute?
description: The future looks quite different with the president in the rearview mirror.
content: Bret Stephens: Gail, we both need to spend December recovering from the dramas and traumas of 2020, so this will be our last conversation until 2021. Looking back on the year so far, do you feel more optimistic, or less, than you did when it began?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: As Virus Upends N.F.L. Schedule, Games Shift to Odd Landing Spots
description: The Ravens and Steelers will play on Wednesday afternoon and the 49ers announced the team will relocate to Arizona for two December games as the coronavirus surge derails pro football’s regular season.
content: After a weekend of question marks and patchwork solutions, the N.F.L. was forced to juggle its schedule yet again on Monday as it tries to finish the full regular season on time amid the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: New York’s Streets Have Brought Relief. Imagine Them Post-Pandemic.
description: Permanent outdoor dining is a no-brainer, but the city could do so much more.
content: It took a pandemic, but New York City is seeing more clearly than ever that its roadways can do more than move cars and trucks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word + Quiz: expedient
description: This word has appeared in 46 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss
title: Exxon Mobil cuts billions in capital spending as oil and gas prices remain low.
description: Exxon Mobil announced on Monday that it would significantly cut spending on exploration and production over the next four years and would write off up to $20 billion of investments in natural gas.
content: Exxon Mobil announced on Monday that it would significantly cut spending on exploration and production over the next four years and would write off up to $20 billion of investments in natural gas.
source.name: The New York Times

description: Ferried by two helicopters, several N.H.L. players and a gold medal-winning figure skater played pickup hockey in a picturesque setting.

title: Australia Demands Apology After Chinese Official’s ‘Repugnant’ Tweet
description: Prime Minister Scott Morrison of Australia condemned a Chinese official’s tweet that showed an Australian soldier with a knife to the throat of an Afghan child, labeling it a “disgusting slur” and demanded an apology.

author: By The Associated Press
title: Iran Mourns Assassinated Nuclear Scientist
description: The Iranian Defense Ministry on Monday held a funeral for Mohsen Fakhrizadeh, one of Iran’s top nuclear scientists who was assassinated last Friday. Officials promised to find and punish those responsible for his killing.
